columns.text: In this exercise, we will determine the following amounts using the concept of cross-rate.

**Exchange rate** is the value of a country's currency *when express in another country's currency.* On the other hand, a **cross-rate** is an implicit exchange rate of two currencies *quoted by another currency.*
\
We will look at Figure 21.1 of this book to answer the questions in the exercise.

## a. 

We are asked to determine if it is better to have $100 or £100.
The £100 when exchange into U.S dollars will give us $168.93 which is *$68.93 greater than* the $100. Therefore, **it is better to have £100.**

## b.

We are asked to determine if it is better to have 100 Swiss francs (SF) or £100.

First, we will compute the value of 100 Swiss francs when expressed in U.S. dollars. We can see in Figure 21.1 that the value of a Swiss franc when express in dollar is **$ 1.1373.** Hence, we will multiply the 100 Swiss francs and the value of a Swiss franc in dollar to determine how many Swiss francs  we can get.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Swiss Francs (SF)} &= \text{SF in dollar} \times {{\text{SF to be exchange}}}\\
&= \text{\$ 1.1373} \times {{\text{SF 100}}}\\
& = \boxed{\text{\$113.73}}
\end{aligned}$$
\
Therefore, if we have 100 Swiss francs, we will get **$113.73**.

Next, we will compute the value of £100 when expressed in U.S. dollars. We can see in Figure 21.1 that the value of a U.K. pound when express in dollar is **$ 1.6893.** Hence, we will multiply the £100 and the value of a pound in dollar to determine how many pounds  we can get.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{British Pounds (£)} &= \text{£ in dollar} \times {{\text{£ to be exchange}}}\\
&= \text{\$ 1.6893} \times {{\text{£ 100}}}\\
& = \boxed{\text{\$168.93}}
\end{aligned}$$
\
Therefore, if we have £ 100, we will get **$168.93**.
The £100 when exchange into U.S dollars will give us $168.93 which is *$55.20 greater than* the 100 Swiss francs when exchange into U.S dollars. Therefore, **it is better to have £100.**

## c. 

We are asked to determine the cross-rate for Swiss francs in terms of British pounds and the cross-rate for British pounds in terms of Swiss francs.

First, we will determine the cross-rate for Swiss francs in terms of British pounds. The value of the Swiss franc when expressed per U.S dollars is **SF 0.8793**. On the other hand, the value of pounds when express in U.S dollars is **$ 1.6893**.

To determine how many Swiss francs we can get for a pound, we will multiply the value of the Swiss franc when expressed per U.S dollars and the value of pound when express in U.S dollars.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Swiss franc (SF)} &= \text{SF per U.S \$} \times {{\text{£ in U.S \$}}}\\
&= \text{SF 0.8793} \times {{\text{\$ 1.6893}}}\\
& = \boxed{\text{SF 1.4854}}
\end{aligned}$$
\
We can get **SF 1.4854** per pound.

Next, we will determine the cross-rate for British pounds in terms of Swiss francs. The value of the British pound when expressed per U.S dollars is **£ 0.5920**. On the other hand, the value of Swiss franc when express in U.S dollars is **$ 1.1373**.

To determine how many British pound we can get for a Swiss franc, we will multiply the value of the British pound when expressed per U.S dollars and the value of Swiss Franc when express in U.S dollars.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{British Pound (£)} &= \text{£ per U.S \$} \times {{\text{SFin U.S \$}}}\\
&= \text{£ 0.5920} \times {{\text{\$ 1.1373}}}\\
& = \boxed{\text{£ 0.6733}}
\end{aligned}$$
\
We can get **£ 0.6733** per Swiss Franc.

As a conclusion, the cross-rate for Swiss francs in terms of British pounds is **SF 1.4854 per pound.** On the other hand, the cross-rate for British pounds in terms of Swiss francs is **£ 0.6733 per Swiss Franc.**
To sum it all up, we have determined the following amounts using the concept of cross-rate.
